STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 13, 2023
JILL SCHREUDER
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - BENTON HA
185 E. MAIN STREET ST.102,
BENTON HARBOR, MI, 49022-4432
Re: License #: CB110403982
Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/11/23-9/13/23. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB110403982
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: JILL SCHREUDER
Name of Agency: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
BENTON HA
Agency Address: 185 E. MAIN STREET ST.102
BENTON HARBOR, MI 49022-4432
Agency Telephone #: 1234567890
Original Issuance Date: 04/21/2020
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel Records
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or her
current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation shall be conducted each year.
3 of 6 employee files reviewed did not contain performance evaluations completed
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
2 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required notifications were made when a placement change occurred.
2

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at
least every 9 months unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
2 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that
periodic dentals were completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services
worker and the social services supervisor.
1 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed contained 1 service plan that did not
have the worker or supervisor signatures. This represents 1 of 25 service plans
reviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans
(2) If parental rights have not been terminated, the
service plan shall include all of the following:
(e)Documentation of how the parents were informed
of their rights and responsibilities in the care of their
child.
1 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
parents were notified of their right during initial service planning.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child’s
placement at least once every month.
1 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed lacked documentation that all required
monthly visits took place with the caregiver and youth in the caregiver's home.
3

CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
1 of 1 adoptive family assessments reviewed was no completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
F OM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
4

6 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required FTMs were held and/or all required FTM paperwork was completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
F OM 722-06H C ASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face
contact in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If
there is more than one caregiver, such as a primary and
secondary caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-
to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the home
at least once each quarter.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a
Placement Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts per month with each child in the first two
months following an initial placement or a placement
change.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
The contact standards detailed in this section are
required anytime a child is placed with their parent or
legal guardian.
Residential or Institutional Setting
When a child is placed in a residential or institutional
setting, the caseworker must have contact with the case
manager/therapist assigned to the child, as described in
this section.
MiSACWIS Documentation
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting, or
safe sleep verification for infants, occurred for each child
participant in the Participant screen within the Social
Work Contact section of MiSACWIS.
4 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required face to face visits were met. These cases were missing documentation of
private meetings with the youth, required quality meeting discussions and/or visits
including the second caregiver in the home at least quarterly.
5

FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
6 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain all required signatures
on PATPs. Missing signatures included parent, caregiver, and youth signatures.
Signatures were missing on 19 of 25 PATPs reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
6

F OM 801-03 M EDICAL PASSPORT
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following: • Foster care
provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care. The actual
date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
Note: Foster care provider includes foster homes,
shelter, adult foster home, fictive kin, relative
placements, detention, and residential facilities.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Each caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the
medical passport verifying that they have sought and
obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement. At
reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification. Non-offending parent,
subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. Note: Non-offending parent with custody of
the child is not considered a foster parent placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for treatment
or services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment
while the foster care case is open, regardless of
7

placement. Subsequent medical passports are not
required.
• Older youth/young adults: Upon initial independent
living placement (youth aged 16 and over). Upon exiting
the foster care system (young adults aged 18 and older)
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed
parties is documented in the electronic case
management record by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
6 of 6 open youth foster care files reviewed did not contain medical passports
completed as required. 4 of the 6 did not have updates completed quarterly and 6 of
the 6 did not have all required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
A DM 300 C HILD ADOPTION ASSESSMENT
Prior to completing the child adoption assessment, the
adoption worker must make a minimum of two face-to-
face contacts with the child, with at least one in the
home, and one face-to-face with the child's current
caregiver, even if the caregiver(s) are not interested in
adopting the child. The contacts must be documented in
the child assessment.
1 of 3 open youth adoption files reviewed contained child adoption assessment that
did not meet all requirement as it did not contain documentation of the 2 required
face to face visits with the youth.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• If parents are marked as "participating" it is expected that required visits,
document review, and signature collection will be completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Utilize supervision and case service plan review to ensure all case contacts are
entered in order to reflect family engagement. If there appear to be gaps in
contact, discuss with the assigned worker if contacts are not being made or if
they are not being documented.
• When reviewing service plans ensure that parents who are not participating are
indicated as such.
8

• Adding all participants to case contacts ensures accurate documentation of
everyone present during contacts, especially face to face visits in the
youth's placement.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was in response to the 2022 licensing renewal
inspection and was approved on 10/6/2022. That CAP addressed 11 violations, 5
of which were repeated during this inspection. Of those 5, 3 have been repeated
during the past 2 inspections. During this inspection 6 violations are found that
were not found during previous inspections. The repeat violations and new
violations are attributed to lack of consistent oversight and accountability at the
program management and supervision level leading to inconsistent and inaccurate
case management practices.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator indicated that there have been difficulties throughout the
year due to the one foster care supervisor leaving without notice and the program
manager demonstrating a decrease in work performance leading to her eventual
departure. Additionally, there has been direct care staff turnover. Due to new staff
and staff who were not receiving adequate oversight, there is a need to
train/retrain all staff. The chief administrator reported the direct care staff are being
supervised by experienced supervisors from the organization's other locations.
Financial Overview
Reviewed annual financial report and no concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The interim program manager and foster care worker reported that the change in
staffing over the past year has been stressful and difficult. The foster care worker
stated she is receiving the support she needs and finds it helpful that she is now
learning how to do her job correctly. The adoption worker stated she is newer to
the agency and was not there when there was turnover. She stated she is
receiving all of the support and guidance she needs while learning her job
responsibilities.
9

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to perform the
required job functions. Paper case files are stored securely in locked cabinets that
prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
September 13, 2023
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 13, 2023
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
10
